ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Data analysis using python, numerical simulations, astronomical observing planning, proposal writing, and the use of python packages taylor made for research in astronomy.
general info abt how astro research is done and some insight abt how the  aspects are done
Many new skills in Python; complete introduction to the field of astronomy, data processing, and the like; learned that astronomy is usually very computation-based!

The course is an excellent elective, catering not only to astrophysics majors but also to those interested in computer science and exploring machine learning applications within the field of astronomy. Serving as an elective for ASTR 330, it delves into scientific computer package writing, providing valuable insights into proposal writing and the scientific processes involved, including some calculations related to stars/galaxies...
python for astrophysics as well as basic math/physics necessary for astro
basics of observational astronomy, telescopes/optics/detectors, programming (Python), accessing catalogues and databases, data analysis techniques/statistics, science writing and communication

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: clear lectures, very understandable what would be tested and what skills we needed to develop, lots of peer interaction

Weaknesses: high-level material was sometimes given extra time in lectures when we were not required to practice it in section or on the homeworks, so some of the content could have been more geared to what we actually covered in section. This is a very minor complaint however because the course was very well organized on the whole
I have gained significant knowledge in the art of crafting scientific proposals.

Overall, a really strong class with clear expectations, challenging but fair problem sets, and engaging material! The final project is unique with very important applications for research success in general. My only suggestion would be one more check in with the professor and TA at the very beginning of the brainstorming period for the final project, just to ensure that students don't go too far down the wrong path with the final and then have to make a lot of changes right before the deadline, but that's a minor nitpick in a really wonderful class. The mock TAC panel at the end of class was a highlight for me.
The course was structured very well

Strengths: engaging lectures, helpful prof and TF, content is super applicable and useful, and the final project is such a great way to synthesize everything learned throughout the semester; no weaknesses I can think of!

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: yes! if youre into astro, def take it. as a physics major, i really enjoyed this course
Yes! Great introduction to astronomy and Python, a super cool field and a super useful skill for a variety of applications.

The course serves as an exceptional elective, attracting not only astrophysics majors but also those interested in computer science and exploring machine learning applications (an elective for ASTR 330). The assignments primarily focus on programming.

Overall, I really loved this course, and I think it's one of the strongest courses in the astro major. I will say I would be wary of this class if you have no coding experience at all. I know its not required, but having a solid few years of Python experience, I think it would have been a significant (and potentially unmanageable) learning curve had I come in fresh. With some experience, problem sets were fair and well-balanced. Professor Rice is wonderful and engaging, and she went out of her way to help us inside and outside of the classshe informed us of REU opportunities, set up guest lectures with interesting professors, organized a YUAG visit and a grad student panel for us to ask questions, etc. The mock panel review was genuinely fun. Its a requirement for the astro major and is comprised of mostly major students, but it is a really great class with real-world applications.
Yes. It's a great intro to astronomy research and scientific programming.
If you're an astrophysics major it's required, but it was also a very enjoyable course

Yes! A must-take for astro majors (or anyone else interested in the intersection of astronomy and data science) as it teaches you the building blocks for astronomy research from coding to reading literature to writing your own proposal
